intros.text: Every quarter we surface a field-tested drill, a quick habit tune-up, and resources you can drop straight into staff briefings.
Use this briefing to keep momentum between formal training days—pick the pieces that fit your team and hit send.
Share the highlights with partners and families so everyone around you can spot, stop, and recover from ransomware attempts.

drills.title: Hospital Blackout Command Drill
drills.summary: Simulate a regional hospital where a ransomware crew has disabled patient record access and imaging. Teams practice running an incident command center while clinicians revert to downtime procedures.

drills.title: Managed Service Provider Containment Sprint
drills.summary: Walk through the first 48 hours after a managed service provider discovers that remote monitoring software was weaponized. Participants triage clients, rotate credentials, and prioritize communications.

drills.title: School District Phishing Cascade
drills.summary: Explore how a single phished staff member leads to district-wide disruption. The drill guides technology leads, principals, and teachers through containment, family outreach, and class continuity decisions.

drills.title: Household Device Lockdown Weekend
drills.summary: Families rehearse what happens when photo backups and shared devices are encrypted. The scenario emphasizes inventorying personal data, practicing offline restores, and discussing ransom demands together.

intel_briefs.headline: Ransomware crews lean on remote monitoring tools
intel_briefs.summary: Threat responders continue to document attackers repurposing legitimate remote management agents that rarely trigger antivirus alerts.
intel_briefs.action: Audit which remote access tools are approved, revoke orphaned accounts, and log interactive sessions.
intel_briefs.source: Field observations aggregated by What is Ransomware

intel_briefs.headline: Multi-channel extortion is the default
intel_briefs.summary: Criminal groups now threaten data leaks, DDoS, and direct-to-customer harassment in the same campaign to force quick payment decisions.
intel_briefs.action: Update crisis communications templates so legal, PR, and support teams can coordinate rapid messaging across channels.

intel_briefs.headline: Education and local government remain high-value targets
intel_briefs.summary: Attackers time intrusions with testing periods, sporting events, or fiscal deadlines when downtime tolerance is low.
intel_briefs.action: Review your calendar for predictable pressure points and pre-stage response staffing around them.

intel_briefs.headline: Backups are getting sabotaged earlier
intel_briefs.summary: Incident reports highlight attackers hunting backup consoles during initial access to corrupt snapshots before encryption starts.
intel_briefs.action: Require MFA on backup tools, keep recent copies offline, and test a restore without production credentials.

habits.title: Rotate shared admin credentials
habits.summary: If multiple people still depend on a single admin login, schedule a rotation window this month and migrate to named accounts with MFA.
steps: Inventory accounts with shared passwords or generic names.
Create individual accounts with least-privilege roles.
Enforce multi-factor authentication before disabling the legacy login.

habits.title: Test a full restore path
habits.summary: Pick one critical system and prove you can restore it from backups without touching production passwords or networks.
steps: Choose a representative workload with business impact.
Restore to an isolated environment or spare hardware.
Document timing gaps and update runbooks while the test is fresh.

habits.title: Sharpen phishing reporting feedback
habits.summary: Close the loop when people report suspicious messages. A fast thank-you note plus next steps keeps the habit alive.
steps: Draft a short auto-reply template with validation and guidance.
Ensure reports land in a queue that analysts actually monitor.
Share sanitized examples during stand-up or staff meetings.

habits.title: Lock in the next tabletop
habits.summary: Do not wait for an incident to schedule the next cross-team rehearsal—book it now while calendars are flexible.
steps: Poll core stakeholders for 60-minute blocks in the next quarter.
Assign a moderator and note-taker with clear roles.
Choose a scenario module from the drills page and tailor injects.
